questiontext.text:
A tennis ball is projected at an angle $$\phi$$ of  33 degrees from horizontal at an initial velocity of  49 m/s, as per the image below.

What is the maximum height (H), that the tennis ball reaches?

{1:NUMERICAL:=36.3:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m

What is the horizontal range (R) that the tennis ball will travel before hitting the ground?

{1:NUMERICAL:=223.8:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)



(Question ID #1).

generalfeedback.text:
First let's look at the $$y$$ component.

Final velocity, $$v$$, is zero at the maximum height; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$49\cdot sin(33)$$; acceleration, $$a$$, is equal to the constant, $$g$$.

Rearranging and applying $$v=u+a\cdot t$$ gives:

$$t=(v-u)/a=(0-(49\cdot sin(33))/-9.8)=2.7$$ s.

Next, applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$h=(26.7\times2.7)+(0.5\times -9.8\times2.7^2)=36.3$$ m.


Next, let's look at the $$x$$ component.

Acceleration, $$a$$, is zero; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$49\cdot cos(33)$$; and the time over which the ball travels before it hits the opponent's racquet is $$2\cdot t$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$R=(2\times49\cdot cos(33)\cdot2.7)=223.8$$ m.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image adapted from ' http://tutor4physics.com/projectilemotion.htm'

hint.text:
HINT

Use the SUVAT equations of motion on both the $$x$$ and $$y$$ components of the tennis ball's motion to solve this question.

generalfeedback.text:

Final velocity, $$v$$, is zero at the maximum height; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$33\cdot sin(55)$$; acceleration, $$a$$, is equal to the constant, $$g$$.

$$t=(v-u)/a=(0-(33\cdot sin(55))/-9.8)=2.8$$ s.

Next, applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$h=(27\times2.8)+(0.5\times -9.8\times2.8^2)=37.3$$ m.


Next, let's look at the $$x$$ component.

Acceleration, $$a$$, is zero; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$33\cdot cos(55)$$; and the time over which the ball travels before it hits the opponent's racquet is $$2\cdot t$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$R=(2\times33\cdot cos(55)\cdot2.8)=104.4$$ m.

questiontext.text:
A tennis ball is projected at an angle $$\phi$$ of  59 degrees from horizontal at an initial velocity of  57 m/s, as per the image below.

What is the maximum height (H), that the tennis ball reaches?

{1:NUMERICAL:=121.8:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m

What is the horizontal range (R) that the tennis ball will travel before hitting the ground?

{1:NUMERICAL:=292.7:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)



(Question ID #31).

generalfeedback.text:
First let's look at the $$y$$ component.

Final velocity, $$v$$, is zero at the maximum height; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$57\cdot sin(59)$$; acceleration, $$a$$, is equal to the constant, $$g$$.

Rearranging and applying $$v=u+a\cdot t$$ gives:

$$t=(v-u)/a=(0-(57\cdot sin(59))/-9.8)=5$$ s.

Next, applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$h=(48.9\times5)+(0.5\times -9.8\times5^2)=121.8$$ m.


Next, let's look at the $$x$$ component.

Acceleration, $$a$$, is zero; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$57\cdot cos(59)$$; and the time over which the ball travels before it hits the opponent's racquet is $$2\cdot t$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$R=(2\times57\cdot cos(59)\cdot5)=292.7$$ m.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

questiontext.text:
A tennis ball is projected at an angle $$\phi$$ of  34 degrees from horizontal at an initial velocity of  58 m/s, as per the image below.

What is the maximum height (H), that the tennis ball reaches?

{1:NUMERICAL:=53.7:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m

What is the horizontal range (R) that the tennis ball will travel before hitting the ground?

{1:NUMERICAL:=318.3:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)



(Question ID #46).

generalfeedback.text:
First let's look at the $$y$$ component.

Final velocity, $$v$$, is zero at the maximum height; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$58\cdot sin(34)$$; acceleration, $$a$$, is equal to the constant, $$g$$.

Rearranging and applying $$v=u+a\cdot t$$ gives:

$$t=(v-u)/a=(0-(58\cdot sin(34))/-9.8)=3.3$$ s.

Next, applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$h=(32.4\times3.3)+(0.5\times -9.8\times3.3^2)=53.7$$ m.


Next, let's look at the $$x$$ component.

Acceleration, $$a$$, is zero; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$58\cdot cos(34)$$; and the time over which the ball travels before it hits the opponent's racquet is $$2\cdot t$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$R=(2\times58\cdot cos(34)\cdot3.3)=318.3$$ m.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

questiontext.text:
A tennis ball is projected at an angle $$\phi$$ of  56 degrees from horizontal at an initial velocity of  55 m/s, as per the image below.

What is the maximum height (H), that the tennis ball reaches?

{1:NUMERICAL:=106.1:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m

What is the horizontal range (R) that the tennis ball will travel before hitting the ground?

{1:NUMERICAL:=286.2:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)



(Question ID #61).

generalfeedback.text:
First let's look at the $$y$$ component.

Final velocity, $$v$$, is zero at the maximum height; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$55\cdot sin(56)$$; acceleration, $$a$$, is equal to the constant, $$g$$.

Rearranging and applying $$v=u+a\cdot t$$ gives:

$$t=(v-u)/a=(0-(55\cdot sin(56))/-9.8)=4.7$$ s.

Next, applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$h=(45.6\times4.7)+(0.5\times -9.8\times4.7^2)=106.1$$ m.


Next, let's look at the $$x$$ component.

Acceleration, $$a$$, is zero; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$55\cdot cos(56)$$; and the time over which the ball travels before it hits the opponent's racquet is $$2\cdot t$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$R=(2\times55\cdot cos(56)\cdot4.7)=286.2$$ m.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

questiontext.text:
A tennis ball is projected at an angle $$\phi$$ of  45 degrees from horizontal at an initial velocity of  45 m/s, as per the image below.

What is the maximum height (H), that the tennis ball reaches?

{1:NUMERICAL:=51.7:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m

What is the horizontal range (R) that the tennis ball will travel before hitting the ground?

{1:NUMERICAL:=206.6:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)



(Question ID #76).

generalfeedback.text:
First let's look at the $$y$$ component.

Final velocity, $$v$$, is zero at the maximum height; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$45\cdot sin(45)$$; acceleration, $$a$$, is equal to the constant, $$g$$.

Rearranging and applying $$v=u+a\cdot t$$ gives:

$$t=(v-u)/a=(0-(45\cdot sin(45))/-9.8)=3.2$$ s.

Next, applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$h=(31.8\times3.2)+(0.5\times -9.8\times3.2^2)=51.7$$ m.


Next, let's look at the $$x$$ component.

Acceleration, $$a$$, is zero; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$45\cdot cos(45)$$; and the time over which the ball travels before it hits the opponent's racquet is $$2\cdot t$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$R=(2\times45\cdot cos(45)\cdot3.2)=206.6$$ m.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

questiontext.text:
A tennis ball is projected at an angle $$\phi$$ of  35 degrees from horizontal at an initial velocity of  51 m/s, as per the image below.

What is the maximum height (H), that the tennis ball reaches?

{1:NUMERICAL:=43.7:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m

What is the horizontal range (R) that the tennis ball will travel before hitting the ground?

{1:NUMERICAL:=249.4:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m

(Give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)



(Question ID #91).

generalfeedback.text:
First let's look at the $$y$$ component.

Final velocity, $$v$$, is zero at the maximum height; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$51\cdot sin(35)$$; acceleration, $$a$$, is equal to the constant, $$g$$.

Rearranging and applying $$v=u+a\cdot t$$ gives:

$$t=(v-u)/a=(0-(51\cdot sin(35))/-9.8)=3$$ s.

Next, applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$h=(29.3\times3)+(0.5\times -9.8\times3^2)=43.7$$ m.


Next, let's look at the $$x$$ component.

Acceleration, $$a$$, is zero; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$51\cdot cos(35)$$; and the time over which the ball travels before it hits the opponent's racquet is $$2\cdot t$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$R=(2\times51\cdot cos(35)\cdot3)=249.4$$ m.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
